math.doubleV

Class AbstractBasis

  • java.lang.Object
    • math.doubleV.AbstractBasis
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    CartesianBasis

    public abstract class AbstractBasis
extends java.lang.Object
    Minimal implementation of basis transformations. Supports only righthanded orthonormal bases (no scaling, now skewing, no reflections).
    Author:
    Eron Gjoni

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractBasis

        public AbstractBasis(Vec3d<?> origin)
        Initialize this basis at the origin. The basis will be righthanded by default.
        Parameters:
        origin -

      • AbstractBasis

        public AbstractBasis(T input)

      • AbstractBasis

        public AbstractBasis(V origin,
                     V x,
                     V y,
                     V z)
        Initialize this basis at the origin. The basis will be backed by a rotation object which presumes right handed chirality. Therefore, the rotation object will align so its local XY plane aligns with this basis' XY plane Afterwards, it will check chirality, and if the basis isn't righthanded, this class will assume the z-axis is the one that's been flipped. If you want to manually specify which axis has been flipped (so that the rotation object aligns with respect to the plane formed by the other two basis vectors) then use the constructor dedicated for that purpose
        Parameters:
        origin -
        x - basis vector direction
        y - basis vector direction
        z - basis vector direction

      • AbstractBasis

        public AbstractBasis(R x,
                     R y,
                     R z)
        Initialize this basis at the origin defined by the base of the @param x Ray. The basis will be backed by a rotation object which presumes right handed chirality. Therefore, the rotation object will align so its local XY plane aligns with this basis' XY plane Afterwards, it will check chirality, and if the basis isn't righthanded, this class will assume the z-axis is the one that's been flipped. If you want to manually specify which axis has been flipped (so that the rotation object aligns with respect to the plane formed by the other two basis vectors) then use the constructor dedicated for that purpose
        Parameters:
        x - basis Ray
        y - basis Ray
        z - basis Ray

      • setToShearXBase

        public <V extends Vec3d<?>> void setToShearXBase(V vec)
        the default Basis implementation is orthonormal, so by default this function will just set @param vec to (1,0,0), but extending (affine) classes can override this to represent the direction and magnitude of the x axis prior to rotation.

      • setToShearYBase

        public <V extends Vec3d<?>> void setToShearYBase(V vec)
        the default Basis implementation is orthonormal, so by default this function will just set @param vec to (0,1,0), but extending (affine) classes can override this to represent the direction and magnitude of the y axis prior to rotation.

      • setToShearZBase

        public <V extends Vec3d<?>> void setToShearZBase(V vec)
        the default Basis implementation is orthonormal, so by default this function will just set @param vec to (0,0,1), but extending (affine) classes can override this to represent the direction and magnitude of the z axis prior to rotation.

      • setToGlobalOf

        public <T extends AbstractBasis> void setToGlobalOf(T localInput,
                                                    T globalOutput)
        sets globalOutput such that the result of this.getLocalOf(globalOutput) == localInput.
        Parameters:
        localInput -
        globalOutput -

      • isAxisFlipped

        public boolean isAxisFlipped(int axis)
        true if the input axis should be multiplied by negative one after rotation. By default, this always returns false. But can be overriden for more advanced implementations allowing for reflection transformations.
        Parameters:
        axis -
        Returns:
        true if axis should be flipped, false otherwise. Default is false.

      • getInverseRotation

        public Rot getInverseRotation()
        Returns:
        a precomputed inverse of the rotation represented by this basis object.
